svg.content: <mxfile host="app.diagrams.net" modified="2021-02-08T14:02:46.305Z" agent="5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/87.0.4280.141 Safari/537.36" etag="fAj3WAZIqayFwicRCjyz" version="14.3.0" type="device"><diagram id="CScF0yH75hDyNazrB8K4" name="Page-1"></diagram></mxfile>

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 238px; height: 1px; padding-top: 20px; margin-left: 1px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 318px; height: 1px; padding-top: 112px; margin-left: 32px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
The internal components can communicate with each others using Orders and Requests.
Orders are messages that contains a header and a body of data.
There are 2 main internal message types :
- The DIRECT orders : Orders sent from one component directly to another one.
- The BROADCAST requests : Orders sent from one component to *ALL* the other ones

switch.text: The internal components can communicate with each oth...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 278px; height: 1px; padding-top: 112px; margin-left: 432px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Let's assume that an application has 2 components,
the component A and the component B
If both components want to be able to send and receive communications, they have to first subscribe to the communication pipeline
A subscription is a list of data, that can contain the component's public id , private key , and signatures
Subscriptions are in the subscription list
Once subscribed, component A can send a message to be, using a provided method.
To receive messages, a component has to listen to communications sent to it (Either direct messages, or broadcast type communications).
To listen, the component must provide its private key

switch.text: Let's assume that an application has 2 compone...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 278px; height: 1px; padding-top: 472px; margin-left: 432px;

display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Here is a description of what an Order and what a Subscription look like.
It is recommended to use a UUID as a private key
(You can find a UUID generator in @/data/state/controllers/guid.js)

div.div:
Component A sends an order to B, the pipeline then adds that order to the mail room.
Component B is listening to the messages that are incoming, once the orders arrives in the mail room, it is read by the pipeline and then sent to B

switch.text: Component A sends an order to B, the pipeline then adds that order to the mail room....
